summary: The offering will be divided between $29 billion in 13-week and $29 billion in 26-week bills.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Sept. 10

headline: An Ethnic Jigsaw Puzzle
summary: The Pashtuns have traditionally dominated Afghanistan, but other ethnic groups outnumber them in big chunks of the country. See where different ethnic groups primarily live and learn more about them.

headline: Town and Country
summary: Tweeds, furs, woollens and silks give this season's fashion a distinctly relaxed feel, with the occasional flourish of city chic. Actor Peter Krause reveals his inner gent

headline: The New Neutrals
summary: Fall's accessory palette of beige, brown and bronze is the ideal complement for pops of bold color and '70s influenced gold jewelry

headline: Pastor to Appear on NBC's 'Today Show'
summary: Terry Jones, the Florida pastor whose plans to burn copies of the Quran on the ninth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, will be in New York City to appear on NBC's "Today Show" Saturday morning.

headline: Oil Continues to Leak in Chicago Suburbs
summary: Oil continued to leak out of a pipeline in the Chicago suburbs, sending crude-oil prices higher on the prospect of extended downtime for a key artery that ships Canadian crude to the U.S.

headline: An Artist Grows With Her Art
summary: Artist Anna Schuleit, one of the youngest MacArthur "genius" prize winners, is known for her ambitious site-specific installations. Her latest measures three stories high.

headline: Comfort Brunch
summary: Buttermilk Channel in Carroll Gardens offers dressed-up comfort foods like fried pork chops with cheddar waffles and pecan-pie French toast.

headline: The 2011 Volkswagen Jetta
summary: Volkswagen's redesigned Jetta is the linchpin of the company's plan to triple U.S. sales by 2018. Hitting dealerships next month, the base model of the four-dour sedan starts at $15,995.

headline: Zyprexa Ruling Is Thrown Out
summary: A federal appeals court threw out class certification in litigation against Eli Lilly over its antipsychotic drug Zyprexa.

headline: Leak Shuts DownNuclear Plant
summary: Entergy Corp. said Friday its Indian Point nuclear-power station in New York was completely offline after the second of two operating units was shut because of a nonradioactive water leak.

headline: Judge Throws Out Suit Against MetLife
summary: A federal judge in Nevada threw out a lawsuit against MetLife that had alleged the insurer misled policyholders over a common type of account life insurers establish for beneficiaries.

headline: Proposal to Repeal Tax Rules Unacceptable, Treasury Says
summary: Business groups have lobbied for a repeal of the new information-reporting rules, which they say are overly burdensome to small companies. A vote is scheduled for Tuesday.

headline: Chakras Fired Up
summary: Backstage before his show, designer Georges Chakra said that his new collection was feminine and sensual. "It moves when you move," he said, suggesting something lighter than air with his hands. "Women will like it because it's young, modern and classy."

headline: Acting Pay Czar Named
summary: The Obama administration tapped Patricia Geoghegan to be the acting U.S. "pay czar," as Kenneth Feinberg marked his last day in the post.

headline: U.S. Open Photos: Day 12
summary: Bob and Mike Bryan of the U.S. beat Aisam-Ul-Haq Qureshi of Pakistan and Rohan Bopanna of India for the men's doubles title, Vera Zvonareva of Russia beat Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark in the women's semifinals, and American Venus Williams and Kim Clijsters of Belgium faced off.

headline: Hello, Duckie
summary: At Duckie Brown's 2011 Spring Season runway show, the designers weren't worried whether the looks would resonate. "We're fortunate enough that we do sell the extraordinary pieces but we have simple pieces that perhaps are more understandable for the average consumer."

headline: Bond Investors Whipsawed
summary: Treasurys have reversed after a long rally, with 10-year notes losing about 2.5% of their value in 10 days, pushing yields up to the highest level in more than a month. The Dow industrials rose 47.53 on Friday.

headline: Burberry Through the Years
summary: From military men to models, screen legends to soap stars, Burberry has dressed them all

headline: Fire Tears Through California Suburb
summary: A gas-line explosion sparked a massive fire in the San Francisco suburb of San Bruno, killing at least four people and destroying several city blocks.

headline: New York Muslims Still Feel Vulnerable
summary: New York-based Muslims shopping on the eve of the holiday of Eid al-Fitr said that despite a Florida pastor's move to drop plans to burn the Quran, that and other controversies still left them feeling dismayed and vulnerable.

headline: Ex-Toyota Attorney's Suit Against Firm Clears Hurdle
summary: A civil racketeering suit filed against Toyota by one of its former lawyers has cleared a significant hurdle as an arbitrator ruled preliminary evidence shows the company hired him to illegally withhold evidence in suits tied to high-profile accidents.

headline: Crude Jumps 3% After Pipeline Leak
summary: Crude futures settled above $76 a barrel after a pipeline leak in Illinois rattled traders worried about its effect on supplies.

headline: BP Continues Work on Broken Pipe
summary: BP continued for a third day to try and remove a drilling pipe from a ruptured deepwater well. The pipe and blowout preventer need to be fished out of 5,000 feet of water before the "bottom kill" can be executed.

headline: PG&E Shares Fall After Explosion
summary: PG&E shares tumbled, wiping out more than $1 billion in market value for the owner of the natural-gas pipeline that exploded in a suburb of San Francisco.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 10
summary: In Friday's pictures, a Pakistani man carries his bed on his back, miners strike in Spain, a Northamptonshire cricketer makes a rare hit and more.

headline: Three Best Ways to Use Location-Based Social Media
summary: More small businesses are using Foursquare, Facebook's Places and other location-based social networks to woo customers and win repeat business. Here are three best ways to get customers to "check in."

headline: Gold Loses Some Appeal
summary: Gold futures retreated farther from record levels as the metal's safe haven allure waned, outweighing support from Bangladesh's purchase of 10 metric tons of gold from the IMF.

headline: Soirees In Place of Runways
summary: During a night of pre-Fashion Week parties, Viktor & Rolf celebrated the fifth anniversary of its fragrance Flowerbomb, Lacoste launched its newest contemporary line "Lacoste L!ve" and socialite Minnie Mortimer debuted her "city mouse meets country mouse" spring collection.

headline: Smithfield to Sell Butterball Stake
summary: Smithfield Foods said it is selling its 49% stake in the Butterball turkey business to joint-venture partner Maxwell Farms for about $175 million.

headline: European Markets Slip
summary: European stock markets ended the week on a subdued note, although London eked out a gain to close above 5500, which some interpreted as a bullish sign for the week ahead.

headline: Big Business to Obama: Thanks, But No Thanks
summary: The White House hoped it would buy peace and tranquility from the K Street business community with its new plan to cut business taxes. The silence from corporate leaders has been deafening.

headline: China Data Bolster Japan Shares
summary: Asian stock markets were mostly higher Friday, as Japanese shares got a boost from rising imports in China. The Nikkei jumped 1.6%

headline: Canada Added Jobs in August
summary: Canada's economy created more jobs than expected in August, with employers in the service sector hiring more full-time workers, while the unemployment rate inched up to 8.1%, as more workers sought jobs.

headline: Wholesale Inventories Rise
summary: Inventories at U.S. wholesalers rose 1.3% in July -- the most in two years -- an unexpected surge that suggested confidence in the economic recovery.

headline: REIT Reality Check
summary: Real estate trusts are in vogue, if you're among those who've made good money on REITs, and you're congratulating yourself on your good fortune, it's time for a reality check, writes Brett Arends.

headline: India July Industrial Output Surges
summary: India's industrial output surged to double-digit growth in July as factories cranked out more cars and refineries processed higher volumes of crude oil.

headline: Greece Set to Woo Europe's Investors
summary: Senior Greek officials will sweep through Europe's financial centers next week to try to convince investors that they shouldn't have to pay ruinous interest rates on their sovereign debt.

headline: Report Cites BA Lapses in 2009 Incident
summary: Air-safety investigators released a report detailing how pilot error caused a "serious incident" last year when a British Airways jet barely avoided hurtling off the end of Caribbean runway.

headline: Volkswagen Sales Soar
summary: Volkswagen said its sales rose 11.2% on a year-to-year basis in August to 545,500 vehicles, driven by soaring demand in China and a rebound in the U.S.

headline: Rudd Looms Over Gillard's Decisions
summary: As Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard gets ready to name her Cabinet, all eyes are on the post of the foreign affairs minister: Kevin Rudd, Gillard's predecessor, is widely tipped to get it.

headline: French Industrial Production Jumps
summary: French industrial production rose well above expectations in July, but economists remain cautious on the fate of France's industrial sector in coming quarters.

headline: Mastercard Sees Surge In China Credit-Card Use
summary: Rapid urbanization expected to propel China to overtake the U.S. as the world's largest credit-card market by 2020, Mastercard said.

headline: Japanese Firms Pursue Bounty Overseas
summary: As companies continue to expand their presence in foreign markets, Tokyo is under pressure to do more to encourage investment at home.

headline: KDDI Names New President
summary: KDDI said it will replace its top executive, who has run the company virtually since its inception from a merger a decade ago, as Japan's second largest mobile phone carrier by subscribers struggles to compete.

headline: Rise in U.K. Producer Prices Softens
summary: U.K. producer prices increased at their weakest annual rates in six months in August, driven largely by a fall in the price of crude oil.

headline: China Property Prices  Unchanged in August
summary: Beijing grapples with measures to cool the real-estate market as analysts say prices aren't likely to cool in the coming months.

headline: NAB's Plan B for AXA Asia Pacific
summary: National Australia Bank is hoping to salvage what would be Australia's biggest ever financial services takeover. Its new pitch may still fall short.

headline: ABB Sees Strong Demand
summary: Engineering company ABB stuck to an upbeat forecast, saying that demand remains robust and a plan to cut $3 billion in costs by the end of the year is on track.

headline: Regulator Plans to Block Virgin Blue-Air NZ Alliance
summary: The Australian competition regulator said it planned to block Virgin Blue's planned alliance with Air New Zealand, its second major blow in as many days.

headline: U.S. Open Photos: Day 11
summary: U.S. players Liezel Huber and Bob Bryan win the mixed-doubles final, and Switzerland's Stanislas Wawrinka lost to Mikhail Youzhny of Russia in the men's quarterfinals.

headline: EPA Seeks Gas-Drilling Facts
summary: The EPA asked nine natural-gas companies and contractors for information on the chemicals used in a new drilling procedure known as hydraulic  fracturing.

headline: Treasurys Pull Back for Second Day
summary: 'The sky is not falling,' so investors loosen grip on Treasurys. The yield on the 10-year note was pushed up to 2.759%.

headline: Weakened Russia Seeks Ties With EU
summary: The severe blow dealt to Russia by the West's financial crisis is prompting a recalibration of Russia's foreign policy. Among the ideas now surfacing in Moscow: a much closer relationship between Russia and the European Union.

headline: Artists Bound by Tradition, If Not Blood
summary: After three decades, the Flying Karamazov Brothers are still juggling art and comedy.

headline: Hints of Problems at Egg Producer
summary: Daily reports by USDA egg graders at a Wright County Egg egg-packing plant showed increasing sanitation issues this summer. Review excerpts from their reports.

headline: Stoopses Dreading Their Weekend Clash
summary: Oklahoma Sooners coach Bob Stoops will face brother Mark, a coach with Florida State, this weekend. A Chad Ochocinco reference is a favorite fantasy-football team name. And The Couch gets ready for a busy weekend.

headline: Should the Fed Go Negative?
summary: Ben Bernanke has a lot more tools for supporting U.S. economic activity through expansionary monetary policy than he discussed in his Jackson Hole speech.

headline: Heyward-Bey's Historically Poor Debut
summary: Darrius Heyward-Bey had only nine catches in 11 starts, the fewest for any receiver to start at least 10 games in a season since 1991.

headline: U.S. Rebukes Health Insurers
summary: The Obama administration told health insurers that it will track those who enact "unjustified" rate increases and may block those companies from a new marketplace for insurance coverage.

headline: Strassel: The Obama Heyday Is Over
summary: With so many Democrats running against the president's agenda in the midterm, change will come in the next Congress, regardless of which party is in control.

headline: Is This Horse Racing's Final Furlong?
summary: With a capacity crowd of 50,000 expected at the St. Leger, Britain's oldest Classic race, at Doncaster in the north of England on Saturday, horse racing in the U.K. might appear to be on a tear. In fact, it's in crisis.

headline: Loathe Him or Not, Brady Has NY Ties
summary: Though he and New York City might be loathe to admit it, Tom Brady is very much tied to this town.

headline: Salvation in Small Steps
summary: With the collapse of various ideologies and totalizing nostrums, human rights became ever more important in world affairs. Brendan Simms reviews Mr. Moyn's "The Last Utopia: Human Rights in History."

headline: Sanchez's Terrific January Seems Like Ages Ago
summary: Mark Sanchez's penchant for throwing into coverage throughout August may have the naturally pessimistic Jets faithful a bit worried.

headline: U.S. Sees Heightened Threat in Mexico
summary: The White House sees the drug-related violence in Mexico as a national security threat and has launched an intelligence review to combat what some are calling a "narcoinsurgency."

headline: On the Road, Kathmandu to Lhasa
summary: When people find out I climb, they usually ask me two questions: Have I ever climbed Everest? Do I want to? No, I say. Still, I was keen on seeing Everest—from a distance.

headline: Traffic Deaths Fall to Lowest Level in Decades
summary: Traffic deaths in the U.S. fell last year to the lowest level since 1950, a milestone government and industry officials credited to safer cars, safer drivers and, possibly, the slow economy.

headline: Venice's Architectural Affair
summary: The Venice Biennale brings together architects, critics, engineers, urban planners, academics and design fans.

headline: Elite Flee Mexican Business Hub
summary: A surge of violence by drug gangs in Monterrey is leading to an exodus of wealthy Mexicans and scores of U.S. and foreign expatriates, dealing a blow one of Latin America's richest and safest cities.

headline: The Rise of Regionality
summary: Terrior is a concept that divides opinion. For proponents, the term is a catchall for the environment that makes up any viticultural site. Opponents of terroir dismiss the term as nothing more than a marketing exercise.

headline: A Guide to This Week's Arts and Entertainment
summary: A look at "The Apprentice," "The Town," "Jack Goes Boating; Plus, "The Great Game: Afghanistan" tours U.S., and Cleveland hosts a garlic festival.

headline: Robert C. Bonner: Mexico Takes On the Drug Cartels
summary: President Calderón is serious about restoring law and order. Here's how the U.S. can help.

headline: Road Warrior: Kris Arnott
summary: The assistant regional general counsel of British American Tobacco counts among the essentials green tea, hot yoga and luggage in a color that will prevent its being confused with anyone else's.

headline: Greg Ip: From Zombie Banks to Zombie Mortgages?
summary: Japan misallocated capital during its lost decade. How the U.S. can avoid its mistakes.

headline: PGA Tour Faces Post-Tiger Era
summary: Longtime Tour commissioner Tim Finchem talks about global competition, expansion into Asia and South America and how to deal with Tiger Woods's diminished presence.

headline: Military Gay Policy Rejected
summary: A federal judge in California struck down the U.S. military's "don't ask, don't tell" policy as unconstitutional.

headline: Bono Brand Goes Out of Africa
summary: When Edun designer Sharon Wauchob unveils her new vision for the label Saturday, most of the clothes on the runway will be produced in China.

headline: Gas Line Had Unusual Construction
summary: The ruptured natural-gas pipeline that exploded and destroyed 58 homes in a San Francisco suburb had an unusual configuration, investigators said.

headline: FAA to Unveil New Pilot-Fatigue Rules
summary: FAA regulators, bucking opposition from major industry groups, are expected Friday to release long-awaited proposals to combat pilot fatigue.

headline: German Banker to Resign
summary: Germany's Bundesbank said board member Thilo Sarrazin is resigning after a public outcry over controversial comments he made about race and ethnicity.

headline: For Venus, a Gulp of Rarefied Air
summary: Venus Williams is flirting with success at a Grand Slam event other than Wimbledon. Ms. Williams, who last won the U.S. Open in 2001, has since been oddly absent from Grand Slam finals not played on grass.

headline: The Fear of a Failure to Communicate
summary: In Tom McCarthy's novel "C," the main character seeks to unlock the mysteries of technology and to find a "solution" to his troubled soul. Alexander Theroux reviews.

headline: Mets Trio Disappoints—but Are Expectations Too High?
summary: Luis Castillo, Carlos Beltran and Oliver Perez skipped out on their visit to Walter Reed—but it would have been naïve to expect perfect attendance from guys who spend their days immersed in a game little boys can play.

headline: Vodafone Streamlines Structure
summary: Vodafone announced a major restructuring of its divisions, placing all the minority stakes the company holds in other mobile operators into a single unit to be managed separately.

headline: Tracking Songs All Over
summary: Next month, Billboard will launch a new ranking for undiscovered artists and a subscription service to help them get noticed by managers, promoters and labels in search of up-and-coming talent.

headline: College Football Gets Crazy With Statues
summary: As more and more schools erect statues for players and coaches, the bar of what makes a legend gets lower.

headline: M. Zuhdi Jasser: Questions for Imam Rauf From an American Muslim
summary: He may not appear to the untrained eye to be an Islamist, but by making Ground Zero an Islamic rather than an American issue he shows his true allegiance.

headline: Give Two Cheers for Our Presumptive Victory in Iraq
summary: In their comments lauding the surges in both Iraq and Afghanistan Stephen Hadley ("The Lessons of Iraq," op-ed, Aug. 31) and Sen. John McCain ("The Surge and Afghanistan," op-ed Aug 31) both glaringly omit acknowledging the fact that if the Bush administration had deployed the overwhelming force called for by the Powell Doctrine, the course of both wars would have been vastly different and, likely, more favorable to the U.S.

headline: SEC Homes In on Lehman
summary: The SEC's probe into the Lehman collapse is zeroing in on an accounting maneuver used to give the appearance the company had reduced its debt levels.

headline: U.S. Marines Rescue Ship From Pirates
summary: U.S. Marines seized control of a German-owned commercial vessel that had been captured by pirates.

headline: Germany's Tobias Twins Shine in Berlin
summary: Born in Transylvania in 1973, and now living in Cologne, the Tobias brothers draw on everything from medieval woodcuts to Ceausescu-era propaganda as raw material for their highly idiosyncratic art.

headline: Better, Cheaper French Cuisine
summary: In Paris during the past couple of years, a new style of restaurant has emerged that is more attuned to the straightened financial circumstances in which many citizens find themselves.

headline: ECB Makes Case for Belt-Tightening
summary: The ECB is pressing the case for fiscal belt-tightening despite an uncertain global recovery, arguing that the benefits from higher private-sector confidence outweigh any drag on demand.

headline: It's All About Pressure Points
summary: As the gap between the elite players narrows, matches come down to a few key points.

headline: Ballet Gets Personal in New Ads
summary: Each evening next week, sexy advertisements will be projected against buildings in neighborhoods such as the Lower East Side and SoHo. While they could be hawking lingerie, what they're selling is ballet.

headline: BP Lawyers Reviewed Accident Report
summary: BP, which billed its Deepwater Horizon investigation as an independent look at the disaster, said its lawyers were allowed to "review" the long-awaited report before it was published.

headline: Money Funds Draw Inflows
summary: Assets in money-market funds jumped $10.55 billion in the latest week, the fifth time in six weeks more money was put into the funds.

headline: An Adopted Linebacker With Unlikely Story
summary: When it comes to Bryan Kehl's path to the NFL, there's something basic that he doesn't know—whether his athletic talent was something bred into him by his parents, his siblings and his Utah childhood, or whether it was coded into his DNA.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Business Watch
summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Polar Relics of Britain's Fatal Journey
summary: Britain's tragic Antarctic expedition during 1910-'13 will be at the center of Christie's exploration sale in London Sept. 22.

headline: Auto Makers Face Twists in China
summary: With drivers elsewhere subdued, China is the global auto industry's great hope—but there are hurdles for GM and others ahead.

headline: 'Gossip Girl' Brings Runway to TV
summary: Episodes of teen drama "Gossip Girl" reflect how intimately the television show has come to associate itself with the fashion industry.

headline: Regulator Opposes NAB, AXA Deal
summary: Australia's competition regulator continued its opposition to National Australia Bank's proposed bid for wealth management firm rival AXA Asia Pacific.

headline: Preppy Pitfall: All That Madras, Not Enough Effort
summary: Did Lisa Birnbach's original "Handbook" drive people lazy?

headline: Joining the 'Best-Dressed' List
summary: Every year, Vanity Fair releases the results of its Annual International Best-Dressed Poll. The list came to life Wednesday with a lunch celebrating its publication at the restaurant co-owned by Graydon Carter.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: Juventus and Sampdoria meet in Italy's Serie A on Sunday in an early-season grudge match.

headline: 3M Goes on Spending Spree
summary: 3M clinched its third deal in two weeks Thursday with an agreement to buy specialty medical-products maker Arizant Inc., highlighting the conglomerate's shift toward using acquisitions to propel its growth.

headline: Demand for Summer Films Cools
summary: Despite tallying the biggest summer box-office haul in history, Hollywood saw far fewer people going to the movies, resulting in the lowest number of tickets sold in at least 13 years.

headline: Beijing Gets Tough on Targets for Energy
summary: Some of China's local governments are rationing power to factories, homes and hospitals in a push to comply with Beijing's call for a reduction in energy intensity.

headline: Tennis Frat Boy for a Day
summary: From Ralph Gardner's point of view, the most important aspect of Peter Bodo's résumé is that he knows his way around the USTA Billy Jean King National Tennis Center better than most.

headline: MTA Cuts Hinder Home Sales
summary: The loss of the V and W subway lines and the scaling back of bus service in all five boroughs hit commuters hard, but also appears to be affecting the property values of homes in their now-abandoned paths.

headline: 3G Picks Burger King Chief
summary: Burger King's current CEO will be succeeded by former railroad executive Bernardo Hees after 3G Capital completes its buyout of the fast-food chain.

headline: Pennsylvania Community Seeks 9/11 Shrine
summary: Community leaders in southwestern Pennsylvania's Somerset County are determined not to let New York City and the Pentagon have the monopoly on memorials telling the story of 9/11.

headline: De Blasio Sets Inquiry Into Girl's Death
summary: Public Advocate Bill de Blasio has launched an official inquiry into how the city failed to prevent the death of a 4-year-old Brooklyn girl whom authorities suspect was abused by her mother.

headline: Sarkozy Faces Strains Over Gypsies
summary: France's President Nicolas Sarkozy faced new pressure, including fresh criticism of his recent law-and-order drive and a police search of his ruling party's headquarters.

headline: Scott Spencer's Small-Town Maelstrom
summary: The author of "Endless Love" discusses his 10th novel, "Man in the Woods," and finding inspiration in car trips, fellow villagers and his own three rescue dogs.

headline: AXA's Asian Agonies
summary: AXA's Asian strategy is back at square one after the French insurer's campaign to gain full control of its Asian operations was thwarted by Australian regulators.

headline: Fine Films From British Books
summary: Cynthia Crossen looks at movie adaptations that did justice to their British literary inspirations—and some that didn't.

headline: Trennert: Treasurys and the Danger of Short-Term Debt
summary: More than 60% of U.S. debt is set to mature within the next three years.

headline: Legends of the Fall
summary: Michael Feinstein and Barbara Cook join forces at the Regency and Sonny Rollins turns 80 this week.

headline: Harvard Gets Middling Grade
summary: The largest college endowment in the U.S. underperformed the broader markets, posting a 11% return in the year ended June 30.

headline: Dissidents: Iran Has Secret Nuclear Site
summary: Iran is developing an underground military installation in the mountains west of Tehran, according to U.S. officials and Iranian dissidents, but the facility's exact purpose is in dispute.

headline: Carreño to Retire From American Ballet Theater
summary: The American Ballet Theatre principal dancer will continue to perform as a guest artist.

headline: Merkel's Stand for Freedom
summary: The German Chancellor defends Danish cartoonist Kurt Westergaard against Islamists.

headline: How I Set (and Temporarily Lost) a World Record
summary: We were glad-handing for Guinness..

headline: China Car Shipments Pick Up
summary: Chinese auto makers shipped 18.7% more vehicles in August than a year earlier, according to data that showed a moderate pickup in growth but that suggested producers are trimming dealer inventories.

headline: Myanmar Seeks Asian Support for Its Ballot
summary: Myanmar's leader received a warm welcome in meetings with top Chinese officials in what analysts said was an effort to shore up China's support before Myanmar's first major election in 20 years.

headline: John Bogle Raises anExtensible Example
summary: John Bogle reiterates his timeless wisdom in "On Mutual Funds, Cheaper is Better" (op-ed, Aug. 27) but states a conclusion that strikes me as too modest: "The huge economies of scale available in managing other people's money have largely been arrogated by fund managers to their own benefit rather than the benefit of fund shareholders."

headline: WSJ Book Index
summary: With data from Nielsen BookScan.
